statement.p: What symmetries (even, odd, periodic) does the function graphed below have?

hint.p: This function is symmetric across the y-axis.

solution.p: This function is symmetric across the y-axis, so it is even.

statement.p: What symmetries (even, odd, periodic) does the function graphed below have?

solution.p: The function is not even, because it is not mirrored across the y-axis.
Assuming it continues as shown, the function is periodic, because the unit shown below is repeated:

Additionally, f(x) is odd. In a function with odd symmetry, if we mirror the right-hand portion of the curve (the portion to the right of the y-axis) across both the y-axis and the x-axis, it lines up with the left-hand portion of the curve.
Since reflecting the right-hand portion of the graph across the y-axis, then the x-axis, gives us f(x), we conclude f(x) is odd.

statement.p: Suppose f(x) is an even function defined for all real numbers. Below is the curve y=f(x) when x \gt 0. Complete the sketch of the curve.

hint.p: Since the function is even, you only have to reflect the portion shown across the y-axis to complete the sketch.

solution.p: Since the function is even, we simply reflect the portion shown across the y-axis to complete the sketch.

statement.p: Suppose f(x) is an odd function defined for all real numbers. Below is the curve y=f(x) when x \gt 0. Complete the sketch of the curve.

hint.p: Since the function is odd, to complete the sketch, reflect the portion shown across the y-axis, then the x-axis.

solution.p: Since the function is odd, to complete the sketch, we reflect the portion shown across the y-axis (shown dashed), then the x-axis (shown in red).

hint.p: A function is even if f(-x)=f(x).

answer.p:
For any real number x, we will show that f(x)=f(x+4\pi).
f(x+4\pi)&=\sin(x+4\pi)+\cos\left(\frac{x+4\pi}{2}\right)
&=\sin(x+4\pi)+\cos\left(\frac{x}{2}+2\pi\right)
&=\sin(x)+\cos\left(\frac{x}{2}\right)
&=f(x)
So, f(x) is periodic.

solution.p:
For any real number x, we will show that f(x)=f(x+4\pi).
f(x+4\pi)&=\sin(x+4\pi)+\cos\left(\frac{x+4\pi}{2}\right)
&=\sin(x+4\pi)+\cos\left(\frac{x}{2}+2\pi\right)
&=\sin(x)+\cos\left(\frac{x}{2}\right)
&=f(x)
So, f(x) is periodic.

introduction.p: In Questions through , find the symmetries of a function from its equation.

statement.p: What symmetries (even, odd, periodic) does f(x) have?

hint.p: Simplify f(-x) to see whether it is the same as f(x), -f(x), or neither.

solution.p: f(x) is not periodic. (You don't really have to justify this, but if you wanted to, you could say something like this. Notice f(0)=1. Whenever x \gt 10, f(x) \gt 1. Then the value of f(0) is not repeated indefinitely, so f(x) is not periodic.)

To decide whether f(x) is even, odd, or neither, simplify f(-x):
f(-x)&=(-x)^4+5(-x)^2+\cos\left((-x)^3\right)
&=x^4+5x^3+\cos(-x) &=x^4+5x^3+\cos(x)
&=f(x)
Since f(-x)=f(x), our function is even.

statement.p: What symmetries (even, odd, periodic) does f(x) have?

hint.p: Simplify f(-x) to see whether it is the same as f(x), -f(x), or neither.

solution.p: It should be clear that f(x) is not periodic. (If you wanted to justify this, you could note that f(x)=0 has exactly two solutions, x=0,\,-{5}. Since the value of f(0) is repeated only twice, and not indefinitely, f(x) is not periodic.)

To decide whether f(x) is odd, even, or neither, we simplify f(-x).
f(-x)&=(-x)^5+5(-x)^{4}
&=-x^5+5x^4
We see that f(-x) is not equal to f(x) or to -f(x). For instance, when x=1:
f(-x)=f(-1)=4,
f(x)=f(1)=6, and
-f(x)=-f(1)=-6.
Since f(-x) is not equal to f(x) or to -f(x), f(x) is neither even nor odd.

statement.p: What is the period of f(x)?

hint.p: Find the smallest value k such that f(x+k)=f(x) for any x in the domain of f.
You may use the fact that the period of g(X)=\tan X is \pi.

statement.p: What is the period of f(x)?

hint.p: It is true that f(x)=f(x+2\pi) for every x in the domain of f(x), but the period is not 2\pi.

solution.p: All together, f(x)=g(x)+h(x) will repeat when both g(x) and h(x) repeat. The least common integer multiple of \dfrac{\pi}{3} and \dfrac{\pi}{2} is \pi. Since g(x) repeats every \dfrac{\pi}{3} units, and h(x) repeats every \dfrac{\pi}{2} units, they will not both repeat until we move \pi units. So, the period of f(x) is \pi.
